natural solution: We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x \end{vmatrix} &= x \begin{vmatrix} -x & 1 \\ 1 & x  \end{vmatrix} - \sin \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & 1 \\ \cos \theta & x \end{vmatrix} + \cos \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & -x \\ \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x theta :: real
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>j. if i = 0 then (if j = 0 then x else (if j = 1 then sin theta else cos theta)) else (if i = 1 then (if j = 0 then -sin theta else (if j = 1 then -x else 1)) else (if j = 0 then cos theta else (if j = 1 then 1 else x)))))) = -x powr 3"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Evaluate
\[\begin{vmatrix} x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is -x^3
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x \end{vmatrix} &= x \begin{vmatrix} -x & 1 \\ 1 & x  \end{vmatrix} - \sin \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & 1 \\ \cos \theta & x \end{vmatrix} + \cos \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & -x \\ \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= x((-x)(x) - (1)(1)) - \sin \theta ((-\sin \theta)(x) - (1)(\cos \theta)) + \cos \theta ((-\sin \theta)(1) - (-x)(\cos \theta)) \\ &= -x^3 - x + x \sin^2 \theta + \sin \theta \cos \theta - \sin \theta \cos \theta + x \cos^2 \theta \\
 &= \boxed{-x^3}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x theta :: real
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>j. if i = 0 then (if j = 0 then x else (if j = 1 then sin theta else cos theta)) else (if i = 1 then (if j = 0 then -sin theta else (if j = 1 then -x else 1)) else (if j = 0 then cos theta else (if j = 1 then 1 else x)))))) = -x powr 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the determinant of the 3 by 3 matrix where the elements are given by the following rules: the element at the first row and first column is $x$, the element at the first row and second column is $\sin(\theta)$, the element at the first row and third column is $\cos(\theta)$, the element at the second row and first column is $-\sin(\theta)$, the element at the second row and second column is $-x$, the element at the second row and third column is $1$, and the elements at the third row are $\cos(\theta)$, $1$, and $x$ respectively. The final answer is $-x^3$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x theta :: real
shows  "x * ((-x) * x - 1 * 1) - sin theta * (- sin theta * x - (- cos theta)) + cos theta * (- sin theta - (- cos theta * - x)) = - x powr 3"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Evaluate
\[\begin{vmatrix} x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is -x^3
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x \end{vmatrix} &= x \begin{vmatrix} -x & 1 \\ 1 & x  \end{vmatrix} - \sin \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & 1 \\ \cos \theta & x \end{vmatrix} + \cos \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & -x \\ \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= x((-x)(x) - (1)(1)) - \sin \theta ((-\sin \theta)(x) - (1)(\cos \theta)) + \cos \theta ((-\sin \theta)(1) - (-x)(\cos \theta)) \\ &= -x^3 - x + x \sin^2 \theta + \sin \theta \cos \theta - \sin \theta \cos \theta + x \cos^2 \theta \\
 &= \boxed{-x^3}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x theta :: real
shows  "x * ((-x) * x - 1 * 1) - sin theta * (- sin theta * x - (- cos theta)) + cos theta * (- sin theta - (- cos theta * - x)) = - x powr 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Prove that the equation $x((-x)x - 1) - \sin(\theta)(-\sin(\theta)x - (-\cos(\theta))) + \cos(\theta)(-\sin(\theta) - (-\cos(\theta)(-x))) = -x^3$ holds true for all real values of $x$ and $\theta$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and theta :: real
shows  "let A = [[x, sin theta, cos theta], [- sin theta, - x, 1], [cos theta, 1, x]]
       in det A = - (x powr 3)"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Evaluate
\[\begin{vmatrix} x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is -x^3
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x \end{vmatrix} &= x \begin{vmatrix} -x & 1 \\ 1 & x  \end{vmatrix} - \sin \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & 1 \\ \cos \theta & x \end{vmatrix} + \cos \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & -x \\ \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= x((-x)(x) - (1)(1)) - \sin \theta ((-\sin \theta)(x) - (1)(\cos \theta)) + \cos \theta ((-\sin \theta)(1) - (-x)(\cos \theta)) \\ &= -x^3 - x + x \sin^2 \theta + \sin \theta \cos \theta - \sin \theta \cos \theta + x \cos^2 \theta \\
 &= \boxed{-x^3}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and theta :: real
shows  "let A = [[x, sin theta, cos theta], [- sin theta, - x, 1], [cos theta, 1, x]]
       in det A = - (x powr 3)"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the determinant of the matrix $A = \begin{bmatrix} x & \sin(\theta) & \cos(\theta) \\ - \sin(\theta) & -x & 1 \\ \cos(\theta) & 1 & x \end{bmatrix}$, where $x$ is a real number and $\theta$ is an angle. The determinant should equal $-x^3$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x theta :: real and M :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. M $ i $ j = 
  (if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then x 
   else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then sin theta
   else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then cos theta
   else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then - sin theta
   else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then - x
   else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then 1
   else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then cos theta
   else if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then 1
   else if i = 3 \<and> j = 3 then x
   else 0)"
shows  "determinant M = - x powr 3"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Evaluate
\[\begin{vmatrix} x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is -x^3
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x \end{vmatrix} &= x \begin{vmatrix} -x & 1 \\ 1 & x  \end{vmatrix} - \sin \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & 1 \\ \cos \theta & x \end{vmatrix} + \cos \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & -x \\ \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= x((-x)(x) - (1)(1)) - \sin \theta ((-\sin \theta)(x) - (1)(\cos \theta)) + \cos \theta ((-\sin \theta)(1) - (-x)(\cos \theta)) \\ &= -x^3 - x + x \sin^2 \theta + \sin \theta \cos \theta - \sin \theta \cos \theta + x \cos^2 \theta \\
 &= \boxed{-x^3}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x theta :: real and M :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. M $ i $ j = 
  (if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then x 
   else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then sin theta
   else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then cos theta
   else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then - sin theta
   else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then - x
   else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then 1
   else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then cos theta
   else if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then 1
   else if i = 3 \<and> j = 3 then x
   else 0)"
shows  "determinant M = - x powr 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem:
Given a 3x3 matrix M whose elements are defined as follows:

- M[1,1] = x
- M[1,2] = sin(theta)
- M[1,3] = cos(theta)
- M[2,1] = -sin(theta)
- M[2,2] = -x
- M[2,3] = 1
- M[3,1] = cos(theta)
- M[3,2] = 1
- M[3,3] = x
- All other elements are 0.

The determinant of this matrix M is -x^3.

theorem
fixes x theta :: real
shows  "x * (-x * x - 1) - sin theta * (-sin theta - cos theta) + cos theta * (1 - cos theta) = -x powr 3"

\[\begin{vmatrix} x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is -x^3

 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x \end{vmatrix} &= x \begin{vmatrix} -x & 1 \\ 1 & x  \end{vmatrix} - \sin \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & 1 \\ \cos \theta & x \end{vmatrix} + \cos \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & -x \\ \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\

 &= \boxed{-x^3}. \end{align}

fixes x theta :: real
shows  "x * (-x * x - 1) - sin theta * (-sin theta - cos theta) + cos theta * (1 - cos theta) = -x powr 3"

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and theta :: real
assumes h0 : "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>j. if i = 0 then if j = 0 then x else if j = 1 then sin theta else cos theta else if i = 1 then if j = 0 then - sin theta else if j = 1 then - x else 1 else if j = 0 then cos theta else if j = 1 then 1 else x))) = - x powr 3"
shows  "- x powr 3 = det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>j. if i = 0 then if j = 0 then x else if j = 1 then sin theta else cos theta else if i = 1 then if j = 0 then - sin theta else if j = 1 then - x else 1 else if j = 0 then cos theta else if j = 1 then 1 else x)))"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Evaluate
\[\begin{vmatrix} x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is -x^3
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x \end{vmatrix} &= x \begin{vmatrix} -x & 1 \\ 1 & x  \end{vmatrix} - \sin \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & 1 \\ \cos \theta & x \end{vmatrix} + \cos \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & -x \\ \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= x((-x)(x) - (1)(1)) - \sin \theta ((-\sin \theta)(x) - (1)(\cos \theta)) + \cos \theta ((-\sin \theta)(1) - (-x)(\cos \theta)) \\ &= -x^3 - x + x \sin^2 \theta + \sin \theta \cos \theta - \sin \theta \cos \theta + x \cos^2 \theta \\
 &= \boxed{-x^3}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and theta :: real
assumes h0 : "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>j. if i = 0 then if j = 0 then x else if j = 1 then sin theta else cos theta else if i = 1 then if j = 0 then - sin theta else if j = 1 then - x else 1 else if j = 0 then cos theta else if j = 1 then 1 else x))) = - x powr 3"
shows  "- x powr 3 = det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>j. if i = 0 then if j = 0 then x else if j = 1 then sin theta else cos theta else if i = 1 then if j = 0 then - sin theta else if j = 1 then - x else 1 else if j = 0 then cos theta else if j = 1 then 1 else x)))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem:
Given a 3x3 matrix where the elements are defined as follows:

- The elements of the first row are $x$, $\sin(\theta)$, and $\cos(\theta)$, respectively.
- The elements of the second row are $-\sin(\theta)$, $-x$, and $1$, respectively.
- The elements of the third row are $\cos(\theta)$, $1$, and $x$, respectively.

It is known that the determinant of this matrix is equal to $-x^3$. Prove that the determinant of this matrix is indeed $-x^3$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x theta :: real
assumes h0 : "x \<in> real"
and h1 : "theta \<in> real"
shows  "(-x * (-x * x) - sin theta * 1 * cos theta + cos theta * -sin theta * 1) - 
        (x * -sin theta * 1 + sin theta * -x * cos theta + 1 * 1 * cos theta) +
        (x * 1 * cos theta + sin theta * -sin theta * x + 1 * 1 * cos theta) = - x powr 3"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Evaluate
\[\begin{vmatrix} x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is -x^3
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x \end{vmatrix} &= x \begin{vmatrix} -x & 1 \\ 1 & x  \end{vmatrix} - \sin \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & 1 \\ \cos \theta & x \end{vmatrix} + \cos \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & -x \\ \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= x((-x)(x) - (1)(1)) - \sin \theta ((-\sin \theta)(x) - (1)(\cos \theta)) + \cos \theta ((-\sin \theta)(1) - (-x)(\cos \theta)) \\ &= -x^3 - x + x \sin^2 \theta + \sin \theta \cos \theta - \sin \theta \cos \theta + x \cos^2 \theta \\
 &= \boxed{-x^3}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x theta :: real
assumes h0 : "x \<in> real"
and h1 : "theta \<in> real"
shows  "(-x * (-x * x) - sin theta * 1 * cos theta + cos theta * -sin theta * 1) - 
        (x * -sin theta * 1 + sin theta * -x * cos theta + 1 * 1 * cos theta) +
        (x * 1 * cos theta + sin theta * -sin theta * x + 1 * 1 * cos theta) = - x powr 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the value of the following expression: $-x^3 - \sin(\theta) \cos(\theta) + \cos(\theta)(-\sin(\theta)) - x\sin(\theta) + \sin(\theta)(-x\cos(\theta)) + \cos(\theta) + x\cos(\theta) + \sin(\theta)(-\sin(\theta)x) + \cos(\theta)$. The final answer is $-x^3$.

\[\begin{vmatrix} x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is -x^3

 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x \end{vmatrix} &= x \begin{vmatrix} -x & 1 \\ 1 & x  \end{vmatrix} - \sin \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & 1 \\ \cos \theta & x \end{vmatrix} + \cos \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & -x \\ \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\

 &= \boxed{-x^3}. \end{align}
 *)

fixes x :: real and theta :: real
shows  "x * ((-x) * x - 1) - sin theta * (-sin theta * x - cos theta) 
+ cos theta * (cos theta - (-sin theta)) = -x powr 3"

a_8.informal problem: Simplify the expression "$x * ((-x) * x - 1) - \sin(\theta) * (-\sin(\theta) * x - \cos(\theta)) + \cos(\theta) * (\cos(\theta) - (-\sin(\theta)))$. The final answer is $-x^3$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and theta :: real and A :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. A $ i $ j = (if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then x
                             else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then sin theta
                             else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then cos theta
                             else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then - sin theta
                             else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then - x
                             else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then 1
                             else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then cos theta
                             else if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then 1
                             else if i = 3 \<and> j = 3 then x
                             else 0)"
shows  "det A = - x powr 3"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Evaluate
\[\begin{vmatrix} x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is -x^3
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x \end{vmatrix} &= x \begin{vmatrix} -x & 1 \\ 1 & x  \end{vmatrix} - \sin \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & 1 \\ \cos \theta & x \end{vmatrix} + \cos \theta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \theta & -x \\ \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= x((-x)(x) - (1)(1)) - \sin \theta ((-\sin \theta)(x) - (1)(\cos \theta)) + \cos \theta ((-\sin \theta)(1) - (-x)(\cos \theta)) \\ &= -x^3 - x + x \sin^2 \theta + \sin \theta \cos \theta - \sin \theta \cos \theta + x \cos^2 \theta \\
 &= \boxed{-x^3}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and theta :: real and A :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. A $ i $ j = (if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then x
                             else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then sin theta
                             else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then cos theta
                             else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then - sin theta
                             else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then - x
                             else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then 1
                             else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then cos theta
                             else if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then 1
                             else if i = 3 \<and> j = 3 then x
                             else 0)"
shows  "det A = - x powr 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem:
Given a 3x3 matrix A, where the elements are defined as follows:
- The element at the 1st row and 1st column is x,
- The element at the 1st row and 2nd column is sin(θ),
- The element at the 1st row and 3rd column is cos(θ),
- The element at the 2nd row and 1st column is -sin(θ),
- The element at the 2nd row and 2nd column is -x,
- The element at the 2nd row and 3rd column is 1,
- The element at the 3rd row and 1st column is cos(θ),
- The element at the 3rd row and 2nd column is 1,
- The element at the 3rd row and 3rd column is x,
- All other elements are 0.

Find the determinant of matrix A. The answer is -x^3.
